{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3490849,"name":"Matiah","username":"shamanm","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T18:35:50.820Z","cooked":"

This will be our team‚Äôs first year designing an elevator and we need some beginner advice. We‚Äôve built the Thrifty Bot elevator kit, and we‚Äôve determined that a 2 stage elevator with our height constraints will be able to translate our end-effector a large enough distance to reach L4 as it doesn‚Äôt but the carriage itself is not high enough to reach the height needed. Our current design uses two extra tubes attached to elevator to get the extra height at full extension, with the tops of the tubes below the height limit when contracted, but I‚Äôm not sure this is the most robust way to do it?

2 stage example 1383√ó584 93.7 KB

I‚Äôm wondering if it would be more robust to build essentially a 2 stage elevator that is like a 3 stage elevator design but without the carriage. However, given our limited experience, we don‚Äôt know how to do the rigging for this kind of elevator, and an advantage of using the above traditional 2 stage design is that we can just essentially use the published Thriftybot CAD and stick some tubes on it.

So two questions: 1) Do you think the first example above with tubes to reach above the carriage will be an effective solution or would it be more effective for us to make something more like a 3 stage elevator without the carriage? and 2) Has anyone already created a 3 stage or carriage-less 2 stage version of the Thriftybot elevator that you are willing to share? I realize that we could probably figure it out and create our own design, but with a small team with limited resources and no elevator experience, I‚Äôd rather have the students focus on the end effectors and other elements of the robot.

Both methods can work. The extended carriage is similar to what we did in 2024 to help our launcher clear the top of our lift.

Lift only:

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

Post about the full robot:

CHAOS 131 CAD Release - 2024 "Double Time" CAD
The official season is over, it‚Äôs time for our CAD release! To save time, we only fully populated 1 side when we had symmetrical mechanisms, so if something looks weird, please look at both sides. This is especially true on the lift. This robot is divided into 3 major subsystems: The Drive This subsystem includes our Bumpers, Electronics, and Intake. Fun Fact: We had initially dismissed an under-the-bumper intake, but revisited it when 95 posted in their build thread and we saw how much‚Ä¶

I think you‚Äôre looking for something like what we‚Äôre doing. The base stage (aka stage 0) doesn‚Äôt move. This and Stage one have the top rail moved to the back side of the elevator to allow for higher extension of stage 1 and the stage 2 carriage. The rail still provides the rigidity. Make sure to keep a minimum overlap between each stage to keep things rigid. Hope this helps.

image219√ó626 16.6 KB

shamanm:

We are essentially doing a variation of this. The carriage is only needed if you‚Äôre going to the floor to pick up coral. We found our design became much simpler by just eliminating the carriage stage, as we chose to not floor pickup in our strategy.

Depending on your rigging style, there may be different issues.
You may want to check out this thread:

Continuous vs cascade lift Technical
Continuous and cascade refers to the cable rigging on a telescoping lift. In continuous rigging, a single cable spools to raise the output. This generally lifts the output stage first and once that is at the end of travel then the next stage goes up (assuming equal friction between stages). [image] In cascade rigging, each stage is connected to a previous one causing all stages to move at the same time. [image]

There are several other elevator related threads on CD as well which may be of help.

We are using standard thrifty, our elevator sits at max height (42"). Our inner track is 1 inch shorter, and the center is very small to max height.

Here are pictures

Generally, for every inch your first stage moves inside of the stationary frame, the 2nd stage also moves the same distance inside the first stage. (So for every inch you move your chain, your last stage moves 2in).

I don‚Äôt think there is anything you can do in a cascade system to change that relationship to allow your carriage to move less per inch so the first stage makes it all the way up. Maybe different pulley diameters on the top and bottom? Someone much smarter then me may be able to answer that.

If theres no way to do that, I think the only solution is to make your middle stage taller if you have enough starting config height to be able to do so.

How much more up are you trying to get out of it?
